title: Holy crap, you guys complain a lot
body:
I rarely visit the boards (hardly ever) but when I do everybody is complaining. Without visiting the boards I wouldn't really be sure who is broken or not, thank you? I am not really sure how to put this but I think you guys need to realize that not everything will be 100% balanced, ever. Some pokemon are stronger others, some neopets are stronger than others & some club penguin puffles will always be cooler. 

I totally respect the fact that some of you might be angry at a specific champion for being OP or whatnot. However, I think we should cool it a bit because this site has way too much negativity at the moment. Thank you. 

+ I love {{champion:16}} and someone told me that she's not a good support anymore & now I feel {{champion:32}} . Why? I enjoy playing her, I don't care if she's broken, weak, overpowered, ugly...

>
> everybody is complaining

That's sort of the point.

The forums are a place for discussing the game. In a section dedicated to feedback on the balance of the game, you're going to run into a majority of people complaining about X, Y and Zed (particularly Zed in some cases).

Now, personally speaking, I would love it if people would learn to format their complaint and give it some thought. It would be even better if they'd also look through the boards and find a thread talking about the subject they want to discuss, so they can get into a discussion (unless it's too big or isn't quite the same subject they want to discuss).

But, really, I wouldn't change it other than that. There are times where I wish people could post less childish-sounding threads...but the point of this section is to talk about the game's balance and design, and a lot of that involves complaining about what needs work. It's nice to see the occasional, "Thanks for this well-designed bit of the game" thread, but it accomplishes much less than criticism.

Actually, there kind of is a reason that League can't seem to attain DotA 2 levels of balance (which some people would claim isn't that good, but I'm with you on that point). 

DotA 2 as a game was launched from beta with a much more developed perspective of what MOBA is and how to do it right. They also had the entirety of LoL, the original DotA, and every other MOBA before them to perfect their formula off of. Now, Dota 2 doesn't have perfect balance (no game with constant DLC will be) but what makes theres better since its initial launch is that they patch the game much, much more frequently on a smaller scale allowing for faster output of material that course corrects the game more frequently. That kind of design model could help LoL a lot, but its problems run deeper.

LoL as a game is stuck in a state of transition. On one hand we have the old school content like Urgot, Mordekaiser, Urgot, Ryze, etc. and on the other hand we have all of the game's newer content, like Azir, Yasuo, Jinx, Kalista, etc. These champions really do not fit in the same balance universe because the design standards for everything from mobility to counterplay to number tuning has changed drastically since League's inception. Riot frequently updates their older content, but because there is so much of it and they have decided to stick to LoL instead of doing what DotA did and launching a sequel game that is fresh and new from the start, we are left with a game that is losing some of what gained its initial audience and hasn't yet ironed out what it should ultimately become. This is the Reason League can't have DotA 2 balance. If DotA hadn't launched DotA 2 as a whole new game, they would undoubtedly face similar issues with outdated mechanics and game style, not to mention the fact that it would have a ton of Technical issues much like LoL does because League runs on a comparatively old system.

Things Dota 2 does that League should do better (and can do if Riot puts some effort into it): 

* The whole Melee vs Ranged dilemma (you hardly notice when someone is ranged or melee in DotA 2 except in certain lane setups). 
* The concept of role (In Dota, roles are much more flexible in general). 
* The frequency of patches and balance updates. 
* The maleability of the meta (DotA 2 has a lot of different ways to play the map, like Trilanes, Offlanes, Duo lanes, Roaming supports, Designated gankers, etc.).
* All playable characters are unlocked from the get go.

So here is the easy fix....there are over 100 champs in this game.  Stop making new champions.  And balance the ones you have left.  There are more than enough to choose from.  If you can't find a champ to play out of the list this game has its time to find a new game.  And if you say you are bored of playing the one hundred or so champs in this game, then it is time to do something other than play online games all day long.

No, it hasn't.  It's actually just the opposite: the most skilled players have gotten skilled enough that even tiny differences become decisive.  High MMR is defined by everyone in it being very skilled (duh), which also means that they're very close to equally skilled.

If you ever see a game where there is a substantial difference in player skill, then you'll see that it doesn't matter what champions anyone is playing.  But of course you don't see that in pro games, because genuinely bad or even mediocre players don't get or keep spots on pro teams.
